Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has six pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 8 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Engineering and design services are required for collecting and organizing facilities and infrastructure data (as-built drawings) into a structured format to make the information relevant and easily accessible for maintenance and operations personnel as well as for engineers and architects working on future projects. Services include collection of existing data as well as the development of the data into a structured format to make the information relevant and easily accessible. Funding will be provided from Plant Services Capital Projects Fund.
  
The District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) #1666 for engineering and design services to provide the District with services for collecting and organizing facilities and infrastructure data (as-built drawings) into a structured format to make the information relevant and easily accessible. The intent of the RFQ was to establish a list of firms qualified to provide the requested services. The RFQ was advertised on Bidnet, and local firms thought to be qualified were contacted directly and encouraged to apply.  On July 29, 2013, the District received responses to the RFQ from:
	 
ARC Document Solutions, Walter P. Moore Engineers and Consultants, and STV/vbn Engineering and Architectural Consulting and Design Services.
	 
A selection committee, comprised of District personnel, deliberated regarding the completeness and quality of responses, experience related to District projects, qualifications and experience of proposed team members, ability to dedicate the appropriate quantity and quality of staff, and fee structure. All of the respondent firms were deemed to meet the qualifications and were invited to provide a technical and price proposal and to present their proposals at interviews that were conducted on September 30, 2013 and October 1, 2013.  
	 
After review of their proposal, and after the conduct of an in person interview, the STV/vbn proposal was judged to best align with the selection criteria established.  Attached is a summary statement of STV/vbn’s interest and expertise and an agreement for services as negotiated with STV/vbn.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen x6150
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong x8289, Steve Schmidt x 6168
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director of Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management Charles Allen recommends that the Board approve the selected firm and contract for services to provide facilities and infrastructure data collection, organization, retention, and access.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
To provide timely restoration of automated data processing and functionality of the Educational Information System (EIS) during and after a disaster (earthquake, fire, flood, etc.), it is necessary to establish a remote site (a colocation site) where backup system hardware and software will be maintained and operated. Therefore, to establish a colocation site the District must contract with a commercial hosting facility and procure associated services, which will ensure continued operations of the backup system. 
	 
Purchasing Services staff, in cooperation with ETS staff, prepared bid documents / specifications to procure colocation site disaster recovery services for the EIS system. The Invitation to Bid document (Bid 1188) requested bids for hosting space in an off-site, remote location to house FHDA back-up servers and data equipment.  The bid specifications also required the vendor to provide network connectivity to the CENIC network for cost efficient data transfer to the district.  Other services provided by the vendor at the remote site will include operational support to monitor and back-up the remote site equipment so that critical application services can be restored quickly in the event of a disaster.
	 
Bid Number 1188 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on November 14 and November 21, 2008.  Additionally, the bid documents were sent to seven (7) vendors and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  One bidder, Abtech Support, submitted a bid response.  SunGard Higher Education had previously submitted an unsolicited proposal for similar colocation services at an estimated cost of $500,000 per annum.  SunGard’s proposal did not include CENIC connectivity.
	 
The bid was awarded to Abtech at the February 2, 2009, board meeting, and a five-year contract was signed between Abtech and the District on March 31, 2009. 
	 
Contract renewal
The contract between Abtech and District is up for renewal March 31, 2014.
	 
Cost analysis
The table below contains the summary of costs for a 4-year contract that includes off-site hosting of two data storage racks and 24 / 7 service support for EIS backup system hardware, operating systems, and telecommunications systems.
	 
EIS colocation disaster recovery site (total cost to district)
One year cost
$ 55,944.00
Recurring Annual Cost (3 years cumulative)
$167,832.00
TOTAL(4 years)
$223,776.00
	 
Submitted by:
Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih, Director of Information Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Vice Chancellor of Technology Joe Moreau to extend the current contract to March 31, 2018, for EIS Hardware Colocation Site Disaster Recovery Services, with Abtech Support in the amount, not to exceed, of $223,766.00.

The Celebrity Forum Speaker Series has been a part of Foothill College for 46 years. The series is an important community event which draws thousands of people each year to the Flint Center. From its founding in 1968, the series has been completely self-supporting and has never used District or college funds for its operation, being financed solely through ticket sales. items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The California Community College Trustees (CCCT) Board of Directors is conducting an election between March 10 and April 25 to fill seven vacancies for three-year terms and one vacancy for a one-year term on the CCCT Board. The Board of Trustees, as a body, is entitled to submit one vote for each of the eight vacancies.  Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The student trustees may cast advisory votes to be used to resolve any ties that result in more than eight candidates being selected.
	 
A list of the 14 candidates who have been nominated, candidate nomination forms, and statements of candidacy are attached. The seven candidates who receive the most votes will serve three-year terms. The eighth top vote getter will complete the term that was vacated. In the event of a tie vote for the last position to be filled, the CCCT Board will vote to break the tie.
	 
The results of the election will be announced at the Community College League of California Trustees Conference, which is being held May 2-4 in Newport Beach.  
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

Revised board policy 2430 (formerly 2210) concerning the governing board's delegation of authority to the Chancellor is presented for review and first reading. The recommended revisions are suggested as good practice in order to meet accreditation standards and also bring the policy into alignment with the language and numbering system of the Community College League of California's (CCLC) Policy and Procedure Service. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, and deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised board policy electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. The policy will be presented for approval of the Board of Trustees at the May 5, 2014, meeting.
	 
References:
Educations Code Sections 70902(d) and 72400
Accreditation Standards IV.B.1.j, IV.B.2, and IV.B.3
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Contract negotiations have been completed. Tentative agreements on two articles were signed in January and February 2014 and recently ratified by CSEA membership. Modifications were made to Articles 10 and 3 of the current Agreement (January 1, 2013-December 31, 2015) between Foothill-De Anza Community College District and California School Employees Association and its Chapter 96. 
	 
The following changes to the language have been made:
	 
Article 3: Union Rights
Language was changed to the steward representation of Foothill College to one grounds and one custodial steward. Language was added to allow CSEA to use District bulletin boards, mailboxes and email as communication methods to members. The language requires CSEA to identify itself on all postings, date posted documents and remove outdated documents. 
	 
Article 8: Leaves
Language was added to clarify the information needed on the application for Staff Development Leave and the number of units required for undergraduate (12 units) and graduate (9 units) for full time status. 
	 
Article 10: Grievance Procedures
Language was added to adjust the timeline to allow for an informal process in attempts to resolve grievances prior to the formal written filing. Language was added to adjust the timeline from 5 days to 10 days for CSEA for second level grievance and arbitration. Language was added to address CSEA’s obligation to send notice to its Board of Directors when submitting disputes to arbitration. 
	 
Submitted by:
Suzanne Pfeiffer, Director of Human Resources, ext. 6109
Additional contact names:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor, Human Resources & Equal Opportunity, ext. 6211
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Suzanne Pfeiffer, Director of Human Resources, recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As a follow-up to the Board’s February 3, 2014, study session regarding the need for an appropriate District Office / Board room, a study of possible sites for such a new building was initiated. 
	 
There are multiple potential sites on land that the District owns for the new building.  Starting with an assumption that somewhere on Foothill College would be the most desirable location for a wide variety of reasons,  four locations at Foothill College were evaluated: parking lot 7 (Option A); the practice field adjacent to lot 1H (Option B); adjacent to the Griffin House (Option C); and east of the tennis courts (Option D).  In addition, for comparative purposes, two options adjacent to the Education Center at Onizuka Air Force Station were studied: a multi-story plan to maximize space for future academic expansion (Option E); and a simpler single-story plan in a similar location (Option F).
	 
The sites were evaluated against factors considered to be important for the location of District offices.  The site designated Option A, located at Foothill College parking lot 7, was identified as the site that best meets the District’s needs.  That site offers a high-profile location, easy access for both the campus community and the public, and adequate space for a building of about 19,500 square feet with adjacent parking.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director
Additional contact names:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval to further develop option A as the potential site for a new District Office / Board Room building

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Measure E project #420, District Office Building Renovation, was intended to renovate and modernize the District Office Building (DOB) for the District Board Room as well as for the Chancellor, Business Services, and Human Resources departments.  However, due to limited Measure E funding and space limitations, this planned renovation is not an adequate solution to meet all of the present and future needs of the District.  Additionally, Measure E and C both have projects related to construction of a data center and office space for ETS staff.  Previous attempts to design an appropriate facility to satisfy all of the needs of ETS have proven cost-prohibitive.  After additional review, and as discussed at the February 3, 2014 Board Study Session, it is anticipated that significant cost savings can be achieved by re-directing ongoing DOB renovation efforts to accommodate ETS needs.  
	 
A contract was awarded to Alten Construction on October 7, 2013 to renovate the DOB, and the project is currently under construction. The District and ETS staff have collaborated with Cody Anderson Wasney Architects to develop a design that adapts the DOB facility to use as office space for the ETS staff.  The project team is preparing to issue revised design instructions to the General Contractor in a series of Work Packages in order to facilitate the Contractor’s flow of work and minimize delay impacts on the project. 
	 
Work Packages to be issued by the architect, resulting in change orders to the contractor, are planned to include abatement and demolition of existing walls and structure; architectural floor plan changes; mechanical, electrical, and plumbing instructions; and architectural finishes. The construction cost of some of these change orders, and the total cost of the work, is anticipated to exceed $50,000.  
	 
In order to facilitate the Contractor’s flow of work and minimize delay impacts on the project, one time approval is requested to issue change directives as follows, subject to subsequent final negotiations and board approval: 
Demolition and associated asbestos removal – Not to Exceed $75,000
Floor plan changes – Not to Exceed $75,000
Submitted by:
Charles Allen x6150
Additional contact names:
Joe Moreau x6120, Art Heinrich x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Charles Allen, Executive Director of Facilities, Operations and Construction Management requests Board authorization to issue change directives as described above, subject to subsequent final negotiations and subsequent board approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In order for the District's wireless network to support the increased speed demand and expanded use, the ETS Networks and Communications team has developed an upgrade and enhancement plan that includes replacing some original components that have reached the end of useful life. The estimated dollar amount for the initial upgrade and enhancement project is approximately $500,000.   
	 
In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651(a) through (d), only the governing board may authorize award of purchase orders that exceed the legally mandated bid threshold, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids.  However, in lieu of the district conducting its own bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community college districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. The Kern County Superintendent of Schools (KCSOS) has awarded a piggybackable contract for wireless equipment to Aruba Networks, Inc. of Sunnyvale, California. This award was the result of a competitive, sealed-bid process conducted in accordance with the California Contract Code, Education Code, and Government Code. The contract is administered through PEPPM National Cooperative Contracts. 
	 
District legal counsel, Mr. John Shupe of Lynch and Shupe, LLP reviewed the contract for validity and provided guidance in our due diligence efforts. Mr. Shupe is satisfied that the risks associated with the contracts we are proposing are minimal and acceptable.
	 
Product Line information can be found at the following website www.peppm.org
	 
The initial purchase will be funded through Measure C, Projects 390 and 391 Wireless Infrastructure and the maintenance and support will be paid for by the A Budget General Fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing
Additional contact names:
Sharon Luciw, Joe Moreau, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for wireless network equipment and related services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the Kern County Superintendent of Schools Bid# 526561 â PEPPM 2014.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The De Anza College Media & Learning Center receives chilled water from the S2-S6 central plant. Chilled water from this plant is only available during certain times of the year, mainly in the warmer, summer months. However, there are five (5) fan coils in the building that serve spaces which require chilled water at times when the central plant is unavailable. The intent of this project is to provide chilled water to these fan coils via an air-cooled chiller. 
	 
The Scope of Work will include the procurement and installation of the new 15-ton air-cooled chiller; providing, installing and tying the new chilled water piping into the existing chilled water loops; integrating the new chiller with the existing building automation system; and updating the control sequences. 
	 
Ratcliff Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1681-261 was legally advertised on February 25 and March 4, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on March 20, 2014, at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTOR
BASE BID AMOUNT
BASE BID AMOUNT incl. allowance
Pullman Construction Inc.
$108,700
$118,700
O.C. McDonald Co., Inc.
$134,500
$144,500
R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc.
$175,400
$185,400
	 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Pullman Construction Inc. (Pullman).  Pullman has successfully completed similar projects for other public entities such as City of Healdsburg, San Francisco Sate University, and City College of San Francisco.
	 
The bid price of $118,700 as submitted by Pullman is within the architect’s construction estimate of $150,000 plus an allowance amount for unanticipated or unforeseen conditions and within the construction budget of $160,000. The project will be constructed with Measure C funds.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1681-261, in the aggregate amount of $118,700 to Pullman Construction, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 18, 2012, the Board authorized the use of the Lease-Leaseback contractor selection process for the Library & ISC Renovation at Foothill College project in accordance with Education Code 81335. 
	 
On December 10, 2012, the Board authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to Kitchell CEM, Inc. (Kitchell) based upon the recommendation of the Selection Committee. The Board of Trustees also approved the Site Lease, Facilities Lease and Construction Provisions as to form and content.  The Preconstruction Services Agreement required Kitchell to prequalify subcontractors, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) to construct the project, and develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule. 
	 
The District requested that Kitchell prepare a GMP for the 3600 Swing Space Build Out Phase.  Kitchell’s GMP for the 3600 Swing Space Build Out Phase of the project is $497,681.00 which is consistent with the project estimate for this scope of work.  The GMP was established based upon the DSA approved set of drawings and specifications for the swing space.  District staff will later seek approval of an amendment to the Facilities Lease agreement that will authorize the Construction Phase of the project based upon DSA-approved construction documents for an amount not to exceed the GMP for construction of the project.   The construction budget for all project phases is $10,500,000.  The Library & ISC project is funded by Measure C. 
	 
This action item is to award the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements to Kitchell and to authorize Kitchell to proceed with the 3600 Swing Space Build Out Phase in order to construct the project. Under the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements, the District will lease District-owned land to the Kitchell, and Kitchell will agree to construct the Project pursuant to the District’s Construction Provisions and Kitchell’s responses to RFQ/RFP 1586-121.  The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the Project, at which time the leases will be terminated.  
	 
Upon execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease, Kitchell will be given access to and control of the site to commence work for the 3600 Swing Space Build Out phase of work. Substantial Completion of the work of the swing space build out will be achieved within 70 calendar days of the start of the work; anticipated completion is June 2014.
	 
Submitted by:
  Charles Allen x6150
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich x6295, Pam Grey x6166
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Accept the GMP in the amount of $497,681.00 for the 3600 Swing Space Build Out Phase and authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, to award the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease to Kitchell CEM, Inc. for the renovation of the Library & ISC at Foothill College.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On November 4, 2013 the Board of Trustees rejected all bids for Bid 1665-141, Painting and Bird Remediation at Foothill College. All five bids submitted exceeded the overall project budget.  The board was advised that District staff would revise the scope of work and evaluate it for rebidding in the future.
	 
The project was re-scoped by removing the sheet metal bird deterrents and the basis of award was modified to allow the contract to be awarded to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder. The lowest bidder would be determined in accordance with Public Contract Code (PCC) 20103.8 (c) which states:
	 
the lowest bid shall be the lowest total of the bid prices on the base contract and those additive or deductive items that when taken in order from a specifically identified list of those items in the bid form and added to, or subtracted from, the base contract, are less than, or equal to, a funding amount publicly disclosed by the District before the first bid is opened.
	 
The bid documents publicly disclosed that the construction project funding amount was $350,000 and included a list of additive and deductive items.  
	 
Prodis Associates Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on January 30, 2014, and February 6, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on February 13, 2014, and a total of twelve (12) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on March 6, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office.  Five (5) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized on the attached spreadsheet:
	 
In applying PCC 20103.8 (c), Purchasing Services determined that Calstate Construction, Inc. is the lowest responsive responsible bidder based upon the Base Bid and Alternates 1 through 3 at a total amount of $319,555. The bid price submitted by Calstate Construction, Inc. is within the overall project budget of $350,000.  Therefore, the Measure C Bond Team recommends that the Board award a contract for the base bid proposal amount plus Alternates 1 through 3 to Calstate Construction, Inc. This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Calstate Construction, Inc. successfully completed Project 109, P.E. Lab Space Remodel and Project 420A, District Office Building Swing Space for the Foothill De Anza Community College District.   
	 
Furthermore, Calstate Construction, Inc. and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1665R-141, Painting and Bird Remediation in the amount of $319,555 for the Base Bid Proposal Amount plus Alternates 1 through 3 to Calstate Construction, Inc.
